properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: 30 to 50 mm of rain is expected by Wednesday morning. A strong low pressure system over Quebec will bring lots of moisture to southern Baffin Island. Rain will fall at Iqaluit and Kimmirut beginning tonight. Rain will continue on Tuesday with 20 to 30 mm expected during the day. By the time the rain tapers off overnight Tuesday night, 30 to 50 mm will have fallen. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-21T11:11:20-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-07-20T19:12:20-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0595301074.2020
Area: Iqaluit, Kimmirut
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Continued: Dam Overflow Alert Continued By Manitoba Infrastructure In The Areas Of Riverdale Municipality And Rm Of Whitehead
properties.Summary:
Description: Continued: This is a Manitoba Emergency Alert. Manitoba Infrastructure is advising that risk of dam failure at the RIVERS RESERVOIR DAM continues at lower risk. Inspection results and lower water levels and flow have lowered the risk of imminent failure and evacuation orders for the inundation area can be lifted. Failure of the dam would result in extreme flooding and dangerous situations. Residents in the inundation zones should remain ready to evacuate on short notice if conditions change. Avoid water bodies, valleys, low lying areas and affected areas. Move to higher ground if required and avoid flooded areas. Up-to-date information is available at www.gov.mb.ca/flooding and www.manitoba511.ca.
Expires: 2020-07-24T16:00:00-05:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization, 2020-07-20T16:37:54-05:00, 05B3D8ED-F77A-4E80-EAE4-E3C5BF6A23ED
Area: Little Saskatchewan River in the Riverdale Municipality and RM of Whitehead.
properties.Author: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: An extended period of very warm weather will continue. Time span: continuing through Wednesday. Maximum daytime temperatures: 28 to 30 degrees Celsius, except cooler along parts of the coast. Minimum overnight temperatures: 16 to 18 degrees Celsius. Locations: central and northeastern Newfoundland. Remarks: Very high temperatures will dominate over most of central and northeastern Newfoundland for the next couple of days. Beyond Wednesday, there is more uncertainty as to how long the heat will persist. Some forecast guidance is suggesting the high temperatures may last through the rest of the week for some areas while other guidance has a bit of a cool down on Thursday into Friday. More details for later in the week will follow in subsequent forecasts. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please call HealthLine 811 for advice on health risks, symptoms and precautions associated with heat. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-07-21T10:24:31-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-07-20T18:25:31-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3115040123.2020
Area: Buchans and the interior, Grand Falls-Windsor and vicinity, Bay of Exploits, Bonavista North, Bonavista Peninsula, Clarenville and vicinity, Gander and vicinity, Green Bay - White Bay, Terra Nova
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Very high temperatures and humidity are expected for much of Nova Scotia. Time span: continuing until Wednesday. Maximum daytime temperatures: 28 to 31 degrees Celsius, except cooler along parts of the coast. Minimum nighttime temperatures: 16 to 20 degrees Celsius. Locations: Nova Scotia. Remarks: Temperatures reaching 28 to 31 degrees Celsius, humidex 36, combined with overnight lows near 16 degrees Celsius are expected for the next couple of days. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. Watch for the effects of heat illness: swelling, rash, cramps, fainting, heat exhaustion, heat stroke and the worsening of some health conditions. Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Information is provided on the Nova Scotia Department of Health and Wellness website at https://novascotia.ca/heat-related-illness/. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-21T11:12:23-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-07-20T19:13:23-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4055854972.2020
Area: Kings County, Annapolis County, Digby County, Lunenburg County, Queens County, Shelburne County, Yarmouth County, Cumberland County - Minas Shore, Cumberland County North and Cobequid Pass, Colchester County - Cobequid Bay, Colchester County North, Hants County, Colchester County - Truro and south, Halifax Metro and Halifax County West, Halifax County - east of Porters Lake, Pictou County, Guysborough County, Antigonish County, Richmond County, Inverness County - south of Mabou, Inverness County - Mabou and north, Victoria County, Sydney Metro and Cape Breton County

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Very high temperatures and humidity are expected for much of New Brunswick. Time span: continuing until Tuesday or Wednesday. Maximum daytime temperatures: 28 to 32 degrees Celsius, except cooler along parts of the coast. Minimum nighttime temperatures: 17 to 20 degrees Celsius. Locations: eastern and central New Brunswick. Remarks: temperatures reaching 32 degrees Celsius and a humidex reaching 39, combined with overnight lows near 18 degrees Celsius, are expected for the next couple of days in southern New Brunswick. In northeastern New Brunswick, very warm temperatures this afternoon and tonight are expected to cool below warning criteria on Tuesday. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. Watch for the effects of heat illness: swelling, rash, cramps, fainting, heat exhaustion, heat stroke and the worsening of some health conditions. Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-21T11:14:39-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-07-20T19:15:39-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1721903070.2020

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Very warm and humid conditions are expected for much of Prince Edward Island. Time span: this afternoon and tonight. Maximum daytime temperatures: 28 to 30 degrees Celsius (Humidex 34 to 37), except cooler along parts of the coast. Minimum nighttime temperatures: 18 degrees. Remarks: a very warm airmass will maintain hot and humid conditions today. Cooler temperatures are expected on Tuesday. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of severe thunderstorms that may be capable of producing strong wind gusts and heavy rain. Maximum rainfall rates: locally 25 mm per hour. Maximum wind gusts: near 80 km/h. Locations: parts of central and southwestern New Brunswick. Time span: mid afternoon till this evening. Remarks: A line of severe thunderstorms could form this afternoon over southwestern New Brunswick and track towards the east into the evening along a cold front. ### Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-21T01:59:44-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-07-20T16:10:44-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4142248662.2020
Area: Fredericton and Southern York County, Oromocto and Sunbury County, Grand Lake and Queens County, St. Stephen and Northern Charlotte County

properties.Title: Fog Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Near zero visibility in fog is expected or occurring. Dense fog will likely persist most of the day today due to a moist easterly flow off Hudson Strait. It should begin to gradually disperse this evening as winds shift slightly more northerly. ### Fog advisories are issued when near zero visibilities in fog are expected or occurring. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-21T04:59:33-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-07-20T14:14:33-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2629786336.2020
